channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for NC

Report E-2023100171

  • Description: During off loading it was discovered that one of the straps had punctured the side of one of the 275 poly tote of araldrite (na1993) and had released 10 gallons of product. Contractors were dispatched for the containment and cleanup of the release.

item.title: Report X-2023090625
item.description:
Report X-2023090625

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-11T15:10:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-11
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The sequence of events of the actual incident are unknown, other than the incident occurred during the Preload Sort. Package had been discovered already in the Hazmat processing area. When discovered, action was taken to start the damage hazmat process. DescribePack: Package failure occurred when two caps on two of the four bottles came loose and leaked into the carton. Caps had not been sealed on tight. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package had already been discovered in the Hazmat holding/processing area, so it had been removed from the origin of incident location. Therefore, minimizing exposure of spillage to those untrained in handing Hazmats.

item.title: Report E-2023100084
item.description:
Report E-2023100084

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-05T15:12:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-21
  • City: CHINA GROVE
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 21, 2023, eighteen (18) 5-gallon pails of UN1133 were crushed and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the dock floor and surrounding cargo. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. The undamaged cargo was down stacked for inspection and wiped down with absorbent pads to remove any residual product. The remaining freight was repalletized for continued processing and shipping. All spent absorbents and impacted pails were collected and containerized into five (5) 55-gallon and one (1) 95-gallon drums for disposal purposes. The drums were properly labeled and possession of the material was taken by R+L.
